title: What happens when a small claims defendant is served a civil bench warrant?
question: The judgment debtor has never shown up to a single hearing, appeal, or debtor's exam. The judge issued a civil bench warrant that states, "The Court orders you to arrest XXX."
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Criminal defense,Criminal arrest,Appealing a criminal conviction,Appeals,Court orders,Small claims court
answers: What may happen is that the debtor will be given a court date and if she fails to appear at that court date, another warrant may be issued. Did the first warrant include a bail amount? sometimes the bail is set at $50. or some very small amount. If the debtor keeps failing to appear, the amount of bail will be increased. Then, you may get your ORAP.

If the Police/Sheriff refuse to honor the court order, there is not a lot that you an do. I do not know what this was the case. Usually, the sheriff/police will take them to jail for a hearing or to court for an immediate hearing. Best option for you is to go speak to the court clerk and ask for guidance.

Be sure to bring with you any documents that you may have indicating that the police/sheriff issued the warrant, but did not arrest.

All of this assumes that you were given the information that when the "warrant was served" it actually was given to the person that you sued. It is possible that there could be other reasons. I rarely hear that a bench warrant was successful. As a warrant for arrest is issued, the police/sheriff/CHP, etc. must honor end effect the warrant. Contact the authority that issued the information to you to determine that they really served the warrant and did not arrest the person.

That is typical. Frankly, sheriffs and police of much better things to do than actually arrest debtors, and even if they did, there is no place to put her (which is why they don't actually arrest).

The bench warrant just sits out there. If the debtor is ever pulled over, a police officer may arrest her (I highly doubt it). The warrant will show up on back ground checks and what not. But face it, you have lost this battle. You still have the upper hand in the war, with the judgement, but you lost this round.

You claim she "has money." How do you know that if you can't find it? If you know she has money, then go after THAT money.
